content: Exemption for certain state and local political committees from notification requirements. Exemption from notification requirements for state and local political committees under section 527(i) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include political committees of state or local candidates and state or local committees of political parties. The amendments will take effect as if included in Public Law 106-230. Exemption for state and local political committees from reporting requirements. The curr_chunk amends the Internal Revenue Code to include qualified State or local political organizations. This is in relation to the exemption for state and local political committees from reporting requirements. The curr_chunk amends the Internal Revenue Code to include qualified State or local political organizations as exempt entities for influencing elections. The term 'qualified State or local political organization' refers to a political organization focused on influencing the selection of individuals for State or local public offices, subject to state reporting requirements. The curr_chunk states that information on expenditures and contributions to a political organization, as well as details on the individuals involved, must be disclosed. The curr_chunk explains that organizations are not required to report certain information if it is already made public by the agency they filed with and available for inspection. Additionally, state law differences do not automatically result in failure to meet reporting requirements. Certain state law differences are disregarded when determining if an organization meets reporting requirements under section 6104(d). This includes differences in the minimum amount of expenditure or contribution required to be reported under State law compared to federal law. Additionally, organizations are not penalized for not identifying certain information as required by State law. The employer of a person who contributes to the organization. The organization must disclose the occupation of contributors, recipients of expenditures, purpose of expenditures, contribution dates, and expenditure dates. An organization can still be considered a qualified State or local political organization even if it makes minor errors in meeting reporting and inspection requirements, as long as these errors are promptly corrected. Qualified State or local political organizations can still maintain their status even if they make minor errors in reporting or inspection, as long as they are promptly corrected. However, organizations controlled or influenced by federal candidates or officeholders are not considered qualified. Candidates for nomination or election to Federal elective public office or individuals holding such office may be subject to certain restrictions if they control or participate in the direction of an organization, solicit contributions to the organization, or direct disbursements by the organization. The amendments made by this section regarding restrictions on candidates for Federal office controlling organizations, soliciting contributions, or directing disbursements shall take effect as if included in Public Law 106-230. Amendments are made to section 6033 of the Internal Revenue Code, specifically regarding returns required by political organizations with gross receipts of $25,000 or more for the taxable year. The Secretary has the discretion to exempt organizations from filing if it is deemed unnecessary for efficient tax administration. The amendments made by this section will take effect as if included in Public Law 106-230. SEC. 4. NOTIFICATION OF INTERACTION OF REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with the Federal Election Commission, shall publicize the effect of the amendments made by this Act and the interaction of requirements to file a notification or report under section 527 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 and reports under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. Information provided shall be included in any appropriate form, instruction, notice, or other guidance issued to the public regarding reporting requirements of political organizations. Information provided under subsection (a) will be included in guidance issued by the Secretary of the Treasury or the Federal Election Commission on reporting requirements for political organizations under section 527 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 and the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. SEC. 5. WAIVER OF FILING AMOUNTS. The Secretary may waive taxes or amounts imposed on organizations for failure to comply with requirements if due to reasonable cause, effective after June 30, 2000. Additionally, there is a provision for notifying about any material changes in information required. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new provision for notifying about material changes in required information within a specified time frame. Effective Dates: The amendments made by subsections (a) and (b) apply to failures occurring after the enactment of this Act. The amendments in subsection (c) take effect as if included in Public Law 106-230, while the amendment in subsection (d) applies to reports and notices filed on or after a specified date. The amendments made by subsections (c), (d), (e)(1), (f), (e)(2), and (e)(3) have specific effective dates based on the enactment of this Act. The amendments made by subsections (e)(1) and (f) apply to reports and notices filed more than 30 days after the enactment of this Act. Subsections (e)(2) and (e)(3) apply to reports filed on or after June 30, 2003. Subsection (g) applies to material changes on or after the enactment of this Act. The amendments made by subsection (g) apply to material changes on or after the date of the enactment of this Act, with a transition rule for changes within a 30-day period. During the 30-day period after the enactment of this Act, a notice under section 527(i) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is not required to be filed within 30 days of a material change or 45 days after the enactment of the Act. Notices, reports, or returns filed with the Secretary of the Treasury before the enactment of the amendments shall remain subject to disclosure provisions of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
